dialogues.speaker: ARK
dialogues.text: Yes, man, Wes. I understand. I know what you need. He looks at Wes with a deep, abiding knowledge.

INT. CHEETAH’S - NIGHT Wes and Ark both slam a SHOT with a beer chaser as. STRIPPERS gyrate behind them. Ark looks to be holding his liquor well, Wes is swervy and loaded. . Ark points to one of the strippers.

dialogues.speaker: ARK
dialogues.text: That is Angie. Nice girl. Her little girl is spelling champion. Give her ten dollars. . Wes does as he’s told.

dialogues.speaker: . WES
dialogues.text: (to Angie) You're doing a fabulous job. Ark hands Wes another shot. He slams it, and tucks some more money in Angie’s g-string. WES (CONT’D) (to Angie) So, Angie, do any of the ladies here do a little hocking on the side? Angie shoots an ANGRY LOOK at Ark.

dialogues.speaker: ARK
dialogues.text: I am sorry Angie. His wedding did not arrive today and he is drunk. Perhaps we go.

dialogues.speaker: WES"
dialogues.text: No, not for me. Not for me, hookers. For my article. This guy wants to marry his hooker, and I thought I could ask her the hooker perspective. Ark starts to lift Wes out of his seat. Ark tucks some more money into Angie’s g-string.

dialogues.speaker: ARK
dialogues.text: Tell Diane good luck for spelling hee. Ark helps a very drunk Wes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FULL HOUSE PARTY has developed. Paul, wearing an apron with the TORSO OF A NAKED MAN printed on it, serves drinks and manages the party like a pro.  1/9/03 . 22. THE CAMERA follows Paul as he weaves through the crowd, until he stops at CATTER. She smiles.as he hands her a drink. Paul is like magical - he always has a drink to give.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: You know I was going to take two Ativan to get through their wedding. That‘s what it takes now - two pills per wedding.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why? Weddings are a bold statement of hope in our crazy world. With booze. Paul downs his drink happily.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: I feel compelled to start the count-back at every wedding.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: The count back. See, if you work backwards, even if I met my future husband in the next fifteen seconds, we'd still have to date a year - minimum - before a proposal, probably eighteen months. - and then a year engagement - 80 the very soonest I could be walking down the aisle is two and half years from now. And that’s if the guy is standing in your kitchen. It's pathetic. Catter downs her drink.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So, you should be happy that Wes and Toby called it off. Two more miserable single people like you.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: No - see that’s the thing. That depresses me, too.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Because it goes to show how unjust it all ig. (MOR2)

dialogues.speaker: CATTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are girls like Toby who get great guys and toss them back, and then there are girls like me who only seem to date guys who play bass and live at home and fear commitment. PAUL. Guess you're screwed. Paul smiles at Catter, kisses her on the head, and moves off to continue hosting. Catter stands there, alone. She walks to a tiny alcove near the kitchen and pulls out her CEL PHONE. She scrolls through until she lands on the name TOBY/WES. She hits SEND. She waits as the Phone rings. And rings. Finally - the machine Picks up. It’s Wes’ voice.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey ~ we're not here - leave a message. Catter hangs up. She stands for a second. She then walks to the kitchen - and as she passes them we stop: WITH ROB AND MOLLIE - Both seriously explaining something to Paul. Paul nods along in between sips of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: So, we're kind of screwed. Most people - they buy china, pots, towels, They work from the registry.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: We got creative,

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: First mistake. I don’t think you can return scuba lessons.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLZE
dialogues.text: That’s like returning fruit. Paul considers their problem.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So you can't return it, Let's take this So-called negative and spruce it up. Are either of you schooled in the art of scuba? Rob and Mollie shake their heads no.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you go.  1/9/03 24. With that, Paul leaves - and the camera follows him as he walks toward - . TOBY - who sits on the kitchen counter, alone, taking it all in. As Paul walks by her, he hands her a drink.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drink up momma. He continues on, but we stay with Toby. She takes a huge sip of her drink. As she brings it down, she notices her hand. Actually, she notices her. ENGAGEMENT RING, which ghe’s still wearing. She plays with it for a second, . spinning it around, before surreptitiously taking it off and putting it in her pocket. EXT. PAUL’S HOUSE - SAME The limo pulls slowly up to the curb in front of Paul's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wes now sits in the front seat with Ark. He is drinking directly out of a bottle of Kettle One, and he is. loaded They both gaze inside at the party through Paul’s front window - the sounds of MUSIC and LAUGHING carrying. from the party into the open limo window. WES . . That used to be my life in there that I’m not invited to. Ark isn't sure how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta piss. With that, Wes gets out of the limo. EXT. PAUL‘S HOUSE - SAME Wes makes his way up onto Paul’s lawn, vodka in hand. He finds a tree to shield him from the street, and PES. And PEES. And PEES. It seems to go on forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROB looks out the window, and sees something. It’s WES. He tells Mollie. Word starts to spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT.’ PAUL’S HOUSE - SAME Wes is still peeing, but now a CROWD of people has started to form on Paul’s stoop. Wes finally finishes. And looks up. He is caught. He looks down at the vodka bottle in his hand and - in a moment of drunken genius - lifts the bottle in the air.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: i came by - to make a toast. I worked hard on this toast and it probably won’t be applicable in a lot of other . situations, and I didn’t want to waste a good toast. So - here goes. I hope you'll indulge me. . Wes takes another slug of vodka. Wes pulls a slip of paper from his pocket and begins to read it to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's to all of you, my dearest friends, who have traveled from every corner of the globe to be here tonight. I hope you're all having a wonderful time, because I’ve certainly had a wonderful time having each of you in my life. Paul, Rob, Mollie and Catter all exchange concerned looks. Wes presses on. WES (CONT’D) And, of course, let’s all raise our glasses to my beautiful bride-NOT-to-be -- I don't know what I would do without you. The crowd is PERFECTLY SILENT. Even Wes seems a little surprised by what has just come out of his mouth. He - finally - feels a little awkward. WES (CONT‘D) So - ummm - have a great time. I hope everyone really is - happy. Goodnight. Just as Wes is about to turn and walk back to the limo, HE AND TOBY MEET EYES. She is standing, one small girl in the big crowd, looking at him. He lets his eyes linger on her, and then ,turns away and gets into the limo. The crowd starts to disperse, but Toby stays on the porch, watching the limo fade into the distance. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: ACT IT
dialogues.text: INT. NOISE OFFICES - WES & TOBY’S OFFICE - DAY Wes sits at his desk, at a loss, as he watches JUDY, 22, sitting across from him, her face buried in her hands. Wes comes around the desk and sits next to her. He hands her a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: It's OK. It’s going to be OK. Take a little sip of water. Judy slowly lifts her face, and takes a sip of water. She looks at Wes. Her face is blotchy from crying.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. You guys are so great together.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I gotta be honest, Judy, I don’t quite understand either.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Now what's going to happen? Are you still gonna work together? Am I still going to be an assistant to both of you? Am I going to have to pick one of you over the other? Am I fired?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Well, we have a lot of things to figure out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This is not right. I've always aspired to have what you guys have - both personally and professionally. And it was all a lie.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it was a lie exactly -

dialogues.speaker: IT WAS TO ME
dialogues.text: dudy begins to cry again, and her face goes back into her hands. Wes just sits there, completely helpless.  1/9/03 27. INT.’ NOISE OFFICES - LOBBY - SAME The elevator doors open. Toby, looking a little tired, steps off the elevator and warily makes her way down the hall. Out of the corner of her eye she spots VIRGINIA KEMP, 40's, very skinny and passive/aggressive. Toby speeds “up, but Virginia is quickly in step with her.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: (bitchy) You're in kinda late. .

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I had a - kinda - rough weekend.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: (false compassion) Oooh. Yeah. I heard about that. Is everything OK with that?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: It happened the day before yesterday, Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. That’s rough.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes. It is.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Rough stuff.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes, Toby stops walking, and looks Virginia in the eye, TOBY (CONT’D) You don't really care about how this is affecting me emotionally, do you?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You're concerned how the writing team you hired is going to continue producing for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has crossed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Can you give us'a little time to feel: ' things out?

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Cool. Thank you. Toby starts toward her office.

dialogues.speaker: . VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: We have lunch with the owner of this magazine at 12:30. That gives you over three hours.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: . VIRGINIA
dialogues.text: Listen, Toby. ' You are the brains of that Operation. I’ve always known that. 1 trust that you will figure this out. Toby is not sure whether to be flattered or frightened as she turns and walks toward her office. INT. NOISE MAGAZINE - TOBY AND WES’ OFFICE - SAME Toby enters the office just as Judy ig leaving. Judy stops, grabs Toby in a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I still love-you both. Judy leaves. Toby slowly enters.’ “TOBY Hey kid. Wes doesn’t look up.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Hey. Silence. Toby walke over to her desk (their desks face each other) and sits down.  1/9/03 29.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: So. Nice showing with the .apeech the other night. .

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Yeah. I really felt like I nailed it. Toby laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: That’s funny. She laughs a little more. TOBY (CONT’D) Funny.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that funny.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Wes, I was just trying to -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Don’t. He gets up and hands her some papers.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here's my pass at the hooker advice letter. Look at it when you can. Toby takes it, seems a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Wes, you know, I'm really glad to see you. I wasn’t sure you’d come in today, or ever, and I know we need to -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I'm going to get some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You don’t drink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I know. Wes averts Toby's eyes as he exits the office. She sits there for a second, stung. Then she turns to the papers and starts to read:  1/3/03 30.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear John, Here’s something I’ve learned quite recently: girls suck. You meet a girl who seems normal - she has a real job and she seems totally acceptable to your friends and family and everything - and then she turns out to be a freak. A total nutcase. Toby's not sure how to take this. WES (CONT'D) . So I think you're on to something here. A prostitute. Why not? She’il never cheat on you, except for having sex with hundreds of guys. And I'm sure she’ll never leave you. I think it’s a solid plan. Toby spins her chair around to her computer, and starts to type. As she types, we hear her voice over and we go

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, the writer of our letter, strides down the hali, reading from a copy of NOISE MAGAZINE that he holds in ene hand. He holds a bouquet of flowers in the other.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This may be hard to believe, John, but I agree with Wes’ advice, if not the sentiment. You really have nothing to lose. FULL SCREEN AS: John slips his KEY CARD into a door.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you come clean about your feelings, at worst, you'll spend a couple of weekends “comparison shopping” for a new call girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John enters to find MELISSA, early 20’s, a beautiful and voluptuous woman in a revealing teddy, lounging on the bed, eating candy from the mini-bar.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And at best, you’1ll have found yourself a new girlfriend who puts out.  1/9/03 31. John sits down on the bed next to Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You look fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: Thanks, baby. He sits, holding the flowers, just staring at her. She starts to remove his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I wanted to get something for you - He hands her the flowers. She takes them, and puts them on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to do that. You already bought me a Grey Goose and a Toblerone from the mini bar. She shows him the empty mini-vodka bottle and candy wrapper, with a sly smile.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You are so cute.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: So are you. He looks at her, smiles, and TACKLES her on the bed. They laugh and wrestle, until they are both a little out of breath. Then, John looks at Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Melissa, I want to ask you something. She unbuckles his belt.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: Mmmm- hmm, He steels himself. And he takes the plunge.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I really like you, and you are so beautiful and fun and I - I just want to know if you’d consider being my girlfriend. Melissa stops what she's doing. She pulls back from John, and looks into his eyes.  1/9/03 . 32.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: I would love to be your girlfriend, baby.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Yeah? ~ Melissa looks at him, touches his cheek, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: Yeah. We see John’s expression turn from one of anxiety to one of PURE BLISS as Melissa grabs him and pulls him down on the bed on top of her. INT. PAUL’S HOUSE - DAY Paul and Catter sit on the floor of the living room. The contents of Paul‘s liquor cabinet, which is EXTENSIVE, are spread around them.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Are you sure you are sticking to the system? Catter smiles, a little bit drunk.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Yes, Paul. I know the system. Organize all liquors alphabetically and by brand within categories. And drink anything less than a shot left in any bottle. Paul pounds what is left in a bottle of tequila.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just making sure, They continue to sort and drink, sort and drink.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: {trying to sound nonchalant) So, have you talked to Wes?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmmm .

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Is he - you know - how’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: ' CATTER
dialogues.text: Do you think maybe I should stop by or make him some - . Paul empties another bottle and looks Catter in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Catter - DON'T. I know you've always had a weird thing for him -

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: I have not!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You told me when you met him, and I quote "I have a weird thing for him.” Gatter’s busted.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: That was 6 years ago. We've been friends now for 6 years. I just want to make sure he’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Please don’t. OK? Catter polishes off a bottle of vodka and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, Wes, Virginia and LUCIUS THOMSON, 50s, sit at a round table in the middle of the posh, crowded restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: I cannot believe that you two have been writing a column for my magazine for years, and this is the first time we have shared a proper meal together.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Please. You have a gagillion dollar industry to - you know - manage -- or whatever. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: Listen, I read the column every month, and from what I hear the book deal for your volume of collected articles is coming together very quickly -  Peer 1/3/03 34.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINA
dialogues.text: It's true - we hope to have. it out by summer.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: ‘ But most of all - I like the story behind the story. ‘ Virginia's face goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: VIRGINA
dialogues.text: Did you read last months advice to that born again virgin? it was - ‘Thomson totally ignores Virginia and barrels on -

dialogues.speaker: . THOMSON
dialogues.text: I mean, you two are these smart, hip kids, who are totally in love and committed to each other, giving relationship advice - it’s perfect. You are still irreverent and smart-aasy - ‘ which I love - but people also believe’ that they can do it, because you guys are doing it. Wes and Toby sneak a look at each other. WES . Yeah, umm - that’s not all that accurate. SILENCE. Virginia is now fully panicked. She and Toby both look at Wes, just waiting.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because, in all honesty, Toby’s not that smart. : TOBY . And Wes is unbelievably un-hip. WES . She mostly has to “sound it out" if the word is more than four letters.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: He likes the Olive Garden for both the food and the ambience. Thomson laughs as he opens his menu. Both Toby and Virgina seem relieved that Wes has decided to play ball. The WAITER walks by. Wes stops him.  f 1/9/03

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Excuse me - how are your stripes prepared?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Ummm -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: He means ribs.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Oh, they’re braised.

dialogues.speaker: . WES
dialogues.text: Thanks. The waiter leaves, Thomson and Virginia are confused,

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Wes won't call them ribs.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: It’s too - bodily.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: So I made up stripes.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: It gives some distance between me and the animal. Thomson looks at Wes and Toby with wonder.

dialogues.speaker: THOMSON
dialogues.text: You guys are quite a team. Wes and Toby look at each other and force a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob and Mollie, in sweatpants, with towels over their shoulders, enter the indoor pool area.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Mollie, I promise. You're overthinking. When we introduce ourselves you're Toby and I'm Wes. That's it. Then we don‘t have to deal with it again.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Were engaged, Rob. I feel like it’s bad luck to pose as a Couple whe didn’t go through with it. 35.  1/9/03 36.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I don’t. I think it's good luck.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: What? Why? Rob is trapped. He has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Listen, maybe we won't even have to lie. I had to tell the woman in the office we were Wes and Toby. But the instructor probably won‘t care who we are.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m sure they won't know it was a wedding present.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Probably not. I have always wanted to scuba.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Exactly. It's going to be fine. Rob and Mollie make their way over to the small group at the far end of the pool. As they get closer, they see that there are TWO WETSUITS remaining, on hangers. On one of them is a BIG BRIDAL VEIL and on the other are a BOW TIE and TAILS. Mollie now GLARES at Rob as MITCH, 30, greets them.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: And you must be Wes and Toby, our newlyweds! The class breaks out into spontaneous clapping and cheers as they beam at Rob and Mollie. Mollie is displeased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunches are finished, and Virginia and Thomson listen as Toby is mid-story. Wes taps his fork.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: So we get the cat back to our apartment - it’s like eight weeks old - and we hear this crazy ruckus upstairs. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go up there - and there’s a bird - a huge crow - flying around our bedroom. I mean - it was like massive, right? She turns to Wes, who’s sort of out of it.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: (recovering) Right. Right. So I put on this -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Windbreaker - and he pulls the hood up so only his eyes are showing. And grabs a tennis racket. . As Toby continues on, we can see Wes’ eyes get further and further away. He’s not even listening anymore. He _ looks around the restaurant - at all the couples eating people laughing. He turns back and looks at Toby as she’s telling the story. She's very animated - gesturing as she talks. And then he notices it. His eyes go wide. IN SLO-MO Toby’s left hand, gesturing, with NO ENGAGEMENT RING ON. She’s taken it off. Wes can‘t believe it. TOBY (CONT’D) - instead of turning on the light he flips the ceiling’ fan switch. So now the bird is going nuts. Wes quickly stands up.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I ummm. Excuse me. Wes abruptly leaves the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wes exits the restaurant and just starts walking. And walking. Either really fast or extremely slow - it’s hard to tell. Then his CEL PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: It's dudy. Where are you? They said you went to the bathroom and never came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re still waiting for you. And your aunt called. And Catter called for you..

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: You mean for Toby.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No, for you. A flicker of confusion passes across Wes’ face.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: ’ Listen, Judy, could you just put me through to Toby? guDY (0.S.) . No problem. Hold on. Judy puts Wes on hold. Hold music comes on. But it’s that Tina Turner song that goes “We don’t need another hero...” It's like nails down a chalkboard. The song gets louder and louder and begins to consume Wes.as he stands on Sunset Blvd. in front of Chin Chin. People continue to walk by as things get blurry - Wes is barely keeping it together, things start to spin. Finally, the song is cut off by: ToBY (0.S.) Wes? Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I can’t do this, Toby. I quit. Wes looks at the phone in shock, as if the phone itself had just said those words. He then slips his phone into his pocket and - out of sheer inertia - keeps walking. EXT. WES’ (& TOBY’S) APARTMENT - LATER Wes, still dazed, comes walking up to his front door to find - Catter. Sitting on the stoop. She seems - drunk.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Uh - hey.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Paul made me help organize his liquor cabinet -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Alphabetize the bottles. Drink up the dregs.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: I gave it my all.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: You're a good friend. She stands, looking at him. He heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: So, I just wanted to come by to see if you were OK. - Wes is unlocking the door. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Not yet. I have to figure some shit out before I'm actually OK.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Right. Catter keeps looking at him. He might cry. Or she might cry. But instead -- CATTER KISSES WES. For a moment, Wes doesn’t resist. And then:

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Catter, Jesus, you're the maid of honor. Catter stares at him - beginning to realize what she’s done.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: IT think you better go. Wes turns and goes inside, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ACT THREE
dialogues.text: INT. WES’ APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both laughing and drinking from 40 oz. beers. We reveal Wes holding the photo, standing in the middle ‘of his living room. There is a CARDBOARD BOX next to him, filled with various CDS, BOOKS, etc. He takes the picture and expertly tosses it into the box. He looks around, satisfied. Then, he reaches over to the coffee table and grabs what looks like an ELECTRIC RAZOR. . He looks at it, and adjusts something. He then lifts it up to his head and we see ~ it’s not a razor - its a HAIR CLIPPER. Without even looking in the mirror, Wes shaves a clean, stripe through his hair. And then another. He continues shaving his head, hair falling around him on the couch, until he is completely bald. He puts down the razor, feels his newly shorn head, and allows himself a small SMILE. ‘EXT. OFFICE BUILDING + DAY Toby, work bag over her shoulder, slips through the revolving door of the Noise offices, and onto sunny Wilshire Blvd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby walks into the small deli like she owns the place.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Bradley, I’m borrowing your People. Toby reaches behind the register and grabs a People Magazine, as BRADLEY, 40s, comes out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Hey, Toby. Toby takes a seat and starts to read her People magazine. A CUTE GUY, late 20s, smiles at Toby. She smiles back, and continues reading her People. Bradley arrives with two sodas.  1/9/03 41. BRADLEY (CONT’D) Cream soda for the lady and Arnold Palmer for my main man -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Wes won’t be - ukh - joining me today.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Bradley is unfazed. He simply takes Wes’ drink, and starts to drink it himself as he heads back to the kitchen. Toby goes back to reading her People magazine. The cute guy watches her as he eats his sandwich. She notices, and gives him ariother awkward smile.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: So, where is he?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Emmm?

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: The guy - where’s the guy? Toby just looks at him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That guy you‘re always in here with. I’ve seen you two. I’m Craig. I work at Schwab - sixth floor.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: So, he's your, what, your business partner?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Ubbhh -

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Ummmm -

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: Your boss? Your grandad? Your pipe fitter? What?  1/9/03 42. Toby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: He's my former fiancee, my recently resigned writing partner and, right now, my smallest fan.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: Your smaliest fan?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Opposite of biggest fan. I thought maybe it was smallest fan. Whatever -- he's not a fan. The cute guy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: Well, that makes one of us. Toby looks up, blushing. She is clearly out of practice , with the flirt.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Oh - ummm -

dialogues.speaker: CUTE GUY
dialogues.text: Have a drink with me after work. Just to help you drown your sorrows. Nothing weird. Toby looks at him, sizing him up. CUTE GUY {CONT’D) Listen, I can’t make it weird, because then I‘d have to find a new deli, and I really like the number three no onion, so that’s like a guarantee that it will be unweird. Toby - almost despite herself - smiles, which is as good as "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very modern, spare office building in Santa Monica. Wes, with his newly shaved head and a funky tan suit, approaches the security desk. MARTY, a beefy black guy, sits at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Wes Brown. I'm here for the Interview - (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: . WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he points to a blow up of an Interview magazine cover on the wall) - uhh - interview. ° Wes laughs nervously. Marty does not. He just punches some keys on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: They got you up in here as Dave.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Uh, I’m Wes,

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: They got you up in here as Dave. Wes just shrugs in acceptance.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: cur To: " CLOSE ON: A NAMETAG, WITH THE NAME “DAVE”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . We pull back to reveal Wes, wearing his nametag, sittin on a couch in a large, spare office. DANIEL, 40s, sits across from him,

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: I really think your column is well- written, or I wouldn't even be considering you for the position -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Thanks - ‘

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: However, I also need to know if you have confidence in your talent as an interviewer as well as a writer. Interviewing requires a whole different skili set than what you are used to using for your column at Noise.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: You know, it’s funny, because in grad school that’s what Toby and I wanted to do. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: " WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We imagined that we would be this interview team - and we worked out this whole “good cop, bad cop” deal that we thought would get everyone to reveal themselves to us. But our first interview at the USC paper was with Matt Dillon, and Toby had been obsessed with him when he was in the Outsiders and had this poster of him from Rumble Fish that she wanted him to sign. So we go to interview him, and she’s supposed to be the bad cop, but she starts good copping, and I really suck as the bad cop, but , evidently she can’t flirt as the bad cop - Wes is enjoying his own story, but sees that he should bring himself back to the question. WES (CONT’D) Anyway, yes. I can do interviews.

dialogues.speaker: DANIEL
dialogues.text: And how did you and Toby break down the writing duties in your partnership? Who exactly did what?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: You know, also very funny. Because we get asked that question all the time, and Toby would always field it. Oh man, what exactly did she say? She has this really funny metaphor that she always used - Wes is trying desperately to remember, and taking way too long to do so. He locks at Daniel, and realizes this interview is going south - fast. WES (CONT’D) Well - enough about Toby. We're not here to interview Toby. We’re here to interview me. He looks at his nametag. WES (CONT‘D) Dave. : Daniel cracks a smile. Wes takes a deep breath and tries to move on.  1/9/03 . 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catter, dressed in a horrible polo shirt and hat that both say GOURMET COURIER, makes her way up Paul's long driveway with a huge WARMER BAG in her arms. She gets to the front door and just opens it and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catter makes her way into the living room to find Paul, Rob and Mollie sitting on the couch. Paul is expertly wielding his remote control at the TV. Catter @rops the bag on the table and sits.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: Paul's TiVo only tapes him Will and Grace,

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Se, your TiVo knows you're gay?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think it’s profiling. Homo-profiling. My TiVo homo~files me. ‘Catter reaches into the warmer bag, pulls out some cartons of food and lays them out on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Pizza with gorgonzola, pounded chicken, penne arrabiatta. Oh, and you guys bought me fusili with pancetta and cream sauce - Catter takes her carton, and plops onto the couch. Paul looks at her WARMER BAG still sitting on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Don’t you have other food in that thing that needs to be delivered?

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. They can waic. Catter heads into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, who's drinking what?  1/9/03 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul follows Catter into the Kitchen. She grabs some glasses out of the cupboard, and turns around to find herself face to face with Paul. He looks her in the eyes. She looks away. He keeps looking at her, but her eyes remain glued to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No. You didn’t. Catter just stands there, holding two glasses, eyes on the ground. PAUL (CONT’D} Catter, please tell me you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: (very softly) I did. It was just a kiss. I just - Paul turns away from her. He is clearly PISSED.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Do you have any respect at all for the little group we have established here? I mean, I know you do the count back, and think you’re going to be single forever, and continue to date wildly inappropriate men who will never marry you - but you cannot take those frustrations out on your friends. We cannot go around kissing each other’s fiancees. I’m not sure about the you, but I don’t have any other friends. So, I'd appreciate it if you didn’t fuck this up. Catter looks like she’s going to cry. Paul is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have done it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Brilliant analysis. Tears spill from Catter’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: (softly) I‘m sorry.  1/9/03 . 47. The tears continue to flow, as Catter runs out of the kitchen, INT. PAUL’S HOUSE- LIVING ROOM - SAME Catter tears through the living room, grabs her warmer bag, and runs out the door. Rob and Mollie watch her - stunned. Paul emerges from the kitchen, expertly carrying three glasses of wine.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: What the hell? Paul passes out the wine.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: I’1l just have a soda or -

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Trust me, in a moment, you’1l want the wine. Or Vicadin. Rob and Mollie look at Paul, their interest definitely piqued.

dialogues.speaker: SPLIT SCREEN WITE
dialogues.text: .CLOSE ON JOHN'S FACE - as he strides through a group of people with MELISSA (THE HOOKER) on his arm. He can barely contain his pride. under this we hear: TOBY (V.0.) . So, our advice to you, John, is - start acting like a boyfriend. Take her out on real dates, introduce her to your friends- We go FULL SCREEN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COCKTAIL PARTY, of well dressed folks in their twenties and thirties, is well underway. John and Melissa make their way through the party.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: - try to sleep with her best friend - you know, boyfriend stuff. PETE, late 30's, approaches John and Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Pete! I didn’t know you were going to be here.  1/9/03 ag.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m back in LA to stay this time.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Really? We should get together, play tennis or something.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Definitely. A beat. Pete looks awkwardly at Melissa. Melissa just looks at John. John realizes his faux-pas.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh my god, I'm sorry. Sweetie, I’m so sorry. Pete, this is Melissa.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: It’s really nice to meet you, too, Pete. An awkward pause. - MELISSA (CONT’D) Well, I’m gonna hit the little girl’s room.

dialogues.speaker: JORN
dialogues.text: OK. I/’11 be here. Melissa leaves. John turns to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wow. Where’d you find her? John smiles. WITH MELISSA ~- As she winds her way back to the bathroom As she goes, she takes in the whole party. Well dressed people laughing, smoking, drinking - clearly with money to burn. She’s feeling a bit out of place. She gets to the bathroom - there are a few girls waiting by the door. She decides not to wait and turns around. She works her way back to John, and as she nears, she can overhear the conversation he’s having with Pete.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know.. It’s really unbelievable. She's - amazing.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wow. I didn’t know you could make that transition. John just shrugs. Pete takes a swig of his drink. PETE (CONT’D) She doesn’t look like a hooker. . John turns and sees Melissa standing there - she heard that last remark. She's not happy. She quickly makes her way out of the party. John follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby sits, sipping a martini with Craig, the cute guy from the deli.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So, are those letters for real? Or do you guys write them yourselves?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: No, they are totally real.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: So, do you have to read through hundreds cf them to find the good ones?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Well, I usually let Wes do that. There is a tiny uncomfortable silence, but Toby presses on. TOBY (CONT’D) I used to read through the letters with him, but it started making me so sad about - like ~ the human condition, you know. I mean, what has transpired in these poor peoples’ lives that they want to marry their hookers or have three ways with their UPS and FEDEX guys, you know?

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: You don’t find those things a little funny?  1/9/03 50.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: A little. But after a while, it would just make me profoundly sad. So, Wes started reading all the mail, and just giving me a few choice letters. He would wade through all the sad stories for me, so I wouldn't have to get so down. “Toby seems struck by what she just said. It's like she has just started to realize what she’s done.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG /
dialogues.text: He sounds like a great partner to have. Toby considers this and nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Then, a waitress approaches, placing an ENORMOUS PLATE OF RIBS in front of the man sitting next to Toby at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. Those are some nice looking stripes.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG
dialogues.text: Eommm?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Stripes. We call them stripes because - you know - ribs - it’s so body-part- specific. Like ordering toes or femurs or something, you know? Toby laughs at her own observation. Craig doesn’t get it. Another moment of uncomfortable silence. TOBY (CONT’D) You know what? Thank you so much for the drink, and this is about to be the rudest thing I’ve ever done - well, not the rudest because I did just cali off a wedding and all - but I think I better just - go. Toby gets up, pulis out some cash and leaves it on the bar. TOBY (CONT’D) See ya at the deli. Number three no onion.  1/9/03 51. Toby doesn’t even wait for a reply before she’s out the door. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mollie and Rob, along with the rest of the class, are all suited up. Rob looks a little freaked.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: So, Wes and Toby - you're up. Mollie gets up and walks toward the pool. Rob doesn’t move. MITCH (CONT’D) Wes, you ready for this? Rob, clearly forgetting his name is Wes, looks off absently and doesn’t respond at all. MITCH (CONT’D} Wes?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Right. Me. Wes. I’m Wes. And ready. Mitch looks at him oddly.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Now remember, you are practicing using your “buddy air.* You and Toby are going to go down, she is going to take out her own air supply - which will be pretty scary at first - but then you are going to give her your buddy air, which feeds off of your tank - and the two of you will ascend together.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yep. Got it. Wes. I’m Wes. Rob and Mollie start to get into the pool. Mollie gives Rob a disapproving look.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You know, it’s actually a perfect exercise for newlyweds. When one cf you loses their own air, the other can share their air, and vice versa. Ycu should do great. Rob looks nervous as he gingerly slips into the water. Mollie smiles and goes under, too.  1/9/03 . 52.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER WATER IN THE JEWISH COMMUNITY CENTER POOL
dialogues.text: Mollie, smiling and giving Rob the thumbs up, takes out her air supply - she is now HOLDING HER BREATH. She swims over to Rob. Rob is breathing from his tank, but looks TOTALLY PANICKED. Moliie motions for Rob to give her his buddy ‘air. Rob just looks at her, panicked. She’motions again and then - with no warning - ROB LEAVES HER THERE AND SWIMS TO THE SURFACE.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SURFACE
dialogues.text: Rob breaks: the surface, taking out his breathing apparatus and gasping for air, dramatically. He spazzes . over to the side.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Oh man. Man that was - crazy. The whole class is looking at him - where’s his new wife? Mollie finally breaks the surface, really gasping for air.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Dude - you get down there and it's like - who knows? Even Rob doesn’t seem convinced by this story.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: I teok out my air supply and motioned for Wes to give me his buddy air, but he panicked.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: You realize, of course, if we had been on an ocean dive; you would have just killed your new bride. Mollie shoots daggers at Rob. Rob tries to lighten the mood.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: So, in terms of it being a good exercise for newlyweds, how’d we do? Mollie walks away, leaving Rob alone on the side of the  ’ 1/9/03 53. EXT. WES‘ (& TOBY'S) APARTMENT - NIGHT Wes sits on the balcony, smoking and staring into space. GIRL’S VOICE Hey. Smokey. Wes looks down onto the sidewalk, where Catter stands, in her Gourmet Courier shirt, looking tired.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Can I come up?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I’m scared of you.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: I won’t touch. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on up. Wes waits. Catter emerges onto the balcony with. two ‘ beers, handing one to Wes. She takes a seat next to him Wes takes an awkward drag off of his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: So, smoking is part of the *New Wes”, I’m guessing?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Looks pretty dumb. WES . Still working out the kinks. Catter summons her courage and turns to Wes.

dialogues.speaker: _ CATTER
dialogues.text: Wes, I need you to know that I’m incredibly sorry about what happened the other night. I don’t know what's wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Clearly, I’m irresistible .

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Yeah, something like that.  1/9/03 . 54. They sit in silence for a moment. CATTER (CONT‘D) OK, maybe I do know what's wrong with me. I’m ingane. I rented Notting Hill recently, and I had to turn it off because I was jealous. Jealous of the love of two FICTIONAL CHARACTERS, Wes. I watch A Wedding Story on the Learning Channel religiously, and get constantly incensed that all of these freaks have found the perfect other freak -- and I , haven't. I just want to find someone already so I can stop obsessively tweezing my eyebrows and fake laughing and just relax. I shouldn't have kissed you, but I was full of rum and possibilities - and I'll just freak if Toby finds out - Wes smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Your secret is safe with me.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Awesome. Moving on. Let’s talk about you. Wes nods as he flicks his ashes into the ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Did you see that flick? That was a nice, natural flick.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: It was a nice flick. Catter looks at Wes. CATTER (CONT’D) Anything else on your mind, perhaps? Wes looks back at her, all seriousness.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: {his voice a little shaky) I don’t know how I’m going to make it alone, Catter. Catter is clearly moved by his admission.  1/9/03 . 55.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Wes, I know this is incredibly hard for you. It’s hard for all of us. We all love both of you. We all feel like we're losing something. And we don’t want to have to choose between you -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: You don’t have to choose. Toby and I - Catter puts her hand on Wes’ hand and squeezes.

dialogues.speaker: , CATTER
dialogues.text: I choose you. Wes looks at her, unsure how to respond. INT. TOBY’S CAR - NIGHT Toby, straight from her ill-fated date, is on the cel phone.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Kip, it’s me. Your sister. Pick up. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, it’s an emergency. Pick up. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I met this girl I want to fix you up with- A MAD CLAMORING THROUGH THE PHONE, as Kip picks up.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What if I‘m still in love with him?

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Mom just sent me home with eight thousand chicken breasts.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I’m serious, Kip. What if I never connect with anyone the way I connect with him?  1/3/03 56. They are both speechless.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me what I should do.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I’ve never had a successful relationship.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Then tell me what Wes and I would tell me to do. Kip thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Talk to him, Toby is silent. KIP (CONT’D) dust talk to him. I’ve never seen two people who can talk about everything or nothing like you guys can. A smile starts to grow on Toby’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Thanks Kip.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Anytime. Toby hangs up the phone and keeps driving. EXT. WES’ (& TOBY’S) APARTMENT - SAME Toby pulls up to her old apartment. Just as she is about to get out of the car, she looks up and, through the windshield, she sees Catter and Wes on the balcony. She studies the image closer - Catter is looking meaningfully at Wes, her hand on his. Toby looks - devastated. She lets her gaze linger on them for a final moment, and then hastily pulls away. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AcT_Iv INT. CATTER’S HYUNDAI - DAY Catter, in her Gourmet Courier t-shirt, jerkily drives the stick shift. Toby rides shot gun, with a big warmer- bag full of food on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: . CATTER
dialogues.text: We haven’t done this in so long -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: {no love) Yeah. .

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Remember that time you were delivering with me, and we delivered to Dean Cain and we just stayed there and ate all of those spring rolls that we just delivered and -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: (still no feeling) Yeah. That was fun. Catter looks at Toby, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Is something wrong? I mean, of course something's wrong, you just called off your wedding - but I mean -

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I saw you with him, Catter. Total uncomfortable silence, Catter’s expression turns to HORROR.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Toby, I - am - so - sorry. Jesus, Toby, I don’t know what to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Tell me why - if you are my best friend - I drive over to find you hanging out with Wes on his balcony last night.  . 1/9/03 58.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Last night? The color starts to return to Catter’s face.

dialogues.speaker: . CATTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (very relieved) Right. Yes. Last night. We were just - you know - just hanging out. As friends.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I know you're just friends. That’s not - the point.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: So, what exactly is the point? Toby looks at Catter, takes a breath, and lets it out.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: You're supposed to pick me.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: What? .

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: In the split. You're supposed to pick me. We were friends in college before either of us even knew Wes.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: So, you go with the one you've known longer? .

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Always? In every circumstance?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I don't know, Catter. But in this case, yes. This is a really weird time for me, and I need your support as my friend. Catter looks at Toby, and in one non-graceful move, inspiring a few honks, pulls over to the curb and james the car into park.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: OK, here’s the thing, Toby. And I know this sucks to hear, because it really sucks to say, but I gotta be honest. I think you're making a huge mistake.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: What? This is just wrong -

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: Wes is a great guy. And the life that you guys have built for yourselves, people dream about that shit. I can't | understand why you would just - chuck it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I shouldn‘t have to defend myself to you. It just didn’t feel right, Catter. That should be enough. It just didn’t feel right.

dialogues.speaker: CATTER
dialogues.text: * Are you're still sure it isn’t right? Toby considers this. Although we see a little doubt starting to creep in, her answer is:

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m sure. I'm pretty sure. Though neither Catter or Toby seem totally convinced. INT. WES’ APARTMENT - AFTERNOON Wes sits on his couch, alone. He’s deep in thought. He’s listening to the long opening to “At Dawn” by My Morning Jacket. As the song kicks in, everything seems to SLOW DOWN and he hears faint voices. He’ turns and sees a YOUNGER WES and TOBY, sort of ghostlike, as if they’re PROJECTED ON THE WALL, struggling to carry a futon up the stairs. Toby, going backwards, is very serious as she keeps falling. Younger Wes can‘t stop laughing. IN THE BATHROOM - Wes peers in, where he sees Toby, standing behind younger Wes, dying his hair. SLIM, now just a little kitten, runs around on the sink, getting dye all over himself.  1/9/03 . 60. IN THE BEDROOM - Wes walks up the stairs goes in, where all around him Younger Wes, with a windbreaker pulled tight over his head, tries unsuccessfully to shoo a bird out of the window. Toby hides in the closet and intermittently looks out at the proceedings. The bird awoops all around the room, narrowly missing the ceiling fan and Wes’ head. -IN THE LIVING ROOM - Wes. then plops back down onto the right side of the couch. Younger Toby and Wes sit, cuddied up, on the left side of the couch. Older Wes sits back and closes his eyes tightly. Slowly, the song fades out, as do the images of Young Toby and Wes.° Then it’s silent. Wes opens his eyes, and he seems - OK. THE PHONE RINGS. Wes goes to pick it up.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Hello. Yes, Daniel, of course, from Interview. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow - I'm surprised. I mean, and thrilled. You have the authority to do that, right, just offer me the job? Right, of course you do. Wow. Wow. Wes looks around, and takes a deep breath. INT. ROB AND MOLLIE’S APARTMENT - DAY Mollie sits at the breakfast room table, alone. Rob enters, in full scuba gear, grabs himself a coke out of the fridge, and joins her at the table.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: You can change at the pool, Rob. Everybody changes there.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Yeah. They make you wear that Speedo under. No one needs to see that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going today, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Because I won't change my clothes in front of other men at the Jewish Community Center?  1/9/03 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Because we may as well admit it. It’s not going to work. I knew posing as a married couple was going to screw us.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I feel like I should go change. Rob gets up and starts to waddle to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: You killed me under the sea.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: It was just practice. So now I will know how to not kill you under the gea.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: It was supposed te be a test of how we could help one another and you suck.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: And you honestly want to break up over this? Mollie just looks at him. MOLLIE. You bailed on me under there, Rob.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: I panicked, Mollie.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLIE
dialogues.text: Well, how do I know you won’t panic again? And bail. Like Toby did to Wes. I didn’t think thac could ever happen to us, but maybe it can, Rob finally gets it. He sits back down with her.

dialogues.speaker: ROB
dialogues.text: Mol, I love you. Listen, it’s true - I'm a terrible, frightened swimmer. And I‘m a little neurotic about changing in front of other men. And I guess ¥ can be a little cheap sometimes. But the point ig - I WILL NEVER BAIL ON YOU. Toby and Wes couldn't make it work. And I'm sorry about that. I really am. But we can. i have no doubt in my mind. This is it for me.  1/9/03 62. Mollie studies his face. A big smiles spreads across her's.

dialogues.speaker: SPLIT SCREEN WITH
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON MELISSA - as she tries to navigate her way down a steep driveway in heels. She’s really upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So good luck, John. We go FULL SCREEN TO: EXT. HOLLYWOOD HILLS HOUSE - NIGHT . John, trailing Melissa, finally catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: The only thing we have left to say to you is -- don't f*ck it up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Melissa, wait. What is going on?

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You're not pissed?

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: What? Nooo. I was just a little warm, so I thought I‘d storm out of the party and down a hillside to get some fresh alr. She continues to storm away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You’re pissed because I told my buddy what you do for a living?

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Melissa -

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: I actually started to believe that - I don’t know - I was your girlfriend or something. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: , MELISSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you just want to tell your little pals that it’s cool that you brought some “hooker to a party.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MELISSA
dialogues.text: Then why did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Honestly? Because I thought lying was worse. Lying would mean I’m ashamed to be with you. And that is so far from the truth. I am so proud to be with you - and I really don’t give a shit what you" do for a living. She looks at him, silent. He clearly means what he's saying.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Melissa, we’ve known each other for five years. And I’ve met a lot of women in those five years. But I have always held each of them up to this imaginary standard of beauty and wit and grace -- and not one of them has been able to measure up. And then one day I realized - that standard was not imaginary. That standard was you. I love you. And no one, no matter what she does for a ~ living, could ever compare. Melissa looks at him - not sure whether she should smile or cry. She kinda does both. EXT. WES’ (& TOBY'S) APARTMENT - NIGHT Wes sits on the patio, smoking. Toby appears behind him.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Hey. I thought there was strange bald smoking man loitering on your balcony.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Nope. Just me.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I, ummm, you know, I just stopped by to get some of my stuff. Toby turns to go back inside. But stops.  1/9/03 : 64.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't really come by to get my stuff. I mean partly, but not entirely.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Did we make a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Me. Me - did I fuck it up? . Wes looks at her for a very long time.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think you did. This is not the answer that Toby was expecting.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Really? Wes measures his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tob, I've spent the last few days alone in this house. And every spoon or printer or doorknob has a story - we have like years of memories packed into every square inch. But the more I thought - the more I realized that’s all I thought about - the past. And what we had was perfect. For then. But it might not be perfect for now. Toby looks at Wes - he really means this.

dialogues.speaker: WES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We grew up together. We've always had each other. But I don’t think either of us ever got to see what it would be like - what we would be like - if we didn’t have that.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Right. That's what Z was trying to tell you before.  vf 1/9/03 . 65.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: But now you're going back on it?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: I was getting scared.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I’m scared, too. Toby sits down as the two of them silently contemplate this admission. . WES (CONT'D) . Toby - I got a job offer today.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Wow. Well, god - congratulations. God - that was - fast, but -

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I don’t want it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Well, then keep on. Look for something better.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I want to keep working with you, you dork.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Oh. OK. How, umm, how is that going to work, with us?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: It just will. You’re my best friend. Toby smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Which is why I’m going to tell you -- Catter kissed me.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Catter kissed me. She apclogized. Everyone thinks she was just -  1/9/03 66.

dialogues.speaker: . TOBY
dialogues.text: Everyone?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Paul, Rob, Mollie, you know -

dialogues.speaker: TORY
dialogues.text: Everyone knows?

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: They didn’t want to upset you, Tob.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: But you don’t mind? Wes looks at her, and smiles genuinely.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: Of course I mind. But until further notice, you.are still the one I’m going to tell everything to. Toby smiles. As they sit in silence, Wes hands her the cigarette and she takes a pull off of it.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY
dialogues.text: Who are we without each other? Wes takes the cigarette back.

dialogues.speaker: WES
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But we’re about to find out. Toby gives a smile and lays her head on Wes’ shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melissa lays in bed, peacefully asleep. We find John, dressed, straightening his tie by the foot of the bed. He moves over to Melissa, kisses her on the forehead. He then pulls out an ENVELOPE from his jacket pocket and places it on the nightstand. He looks at her one last time and ieaves. As he shuts the door, Melissa stirs. She turns over to find John gone and the envelope on the nightstand. Her peacefulness is quickly overtaken by sadness. She slowly reaches over and takes the envelope.  1/9/03 . 67. She opens it warily, and pulls out a VELVET POUCH. Curious, she reaches in and pulls out a HUGE ENGAGEMENT RING. She grasps it tightly, relieved and ecstatic. She lays back down - a smile spreading across her face. INT. PAUL‘S HOUSE - NIGHT A view from outside Paul’s big bay window. Inside we can see the group gathered - Paul, Catter, Rob and Mollie - all sitting in the kitchen, eating dinner. Paul’s continually up and down, filling people’s glasses with wine. They’re having fun but the group seems - small. INT. WES’ (& TORY’ s) APARTMENT - NIGHT Wes and Toby are in the living room - she’s packing up boxes, he’s laying on the couch watching TV. She plops on the floor and starts watching too. ON TV - they’re watching the video from their rehearsal _ dinner. The still picture montage - their lives up until this point. Wes and Toby watch this, together. Not happy, not sad, just ready for what’s to come. FADE OUT.
